comment: It seems the unwitnessed meaning requires some “reinforcement” from other elements, see Kozintseva (2000: 410), though Kozintseva considers the form to have indirect evidential meaning.
Perfect requires “reinforcement” to express indirect evidentiality (Shiraliev & Sevortyan 1971: 127); According to Johanson (2018: 514) it has lost the indirect evidential meaning.
Perfect also has mirative meaning, according to Tatevosov (2007).
Evidential meaning of the Perfect is described in Desheriev (1963); Molochieva describes an inferential intepretation, but claims no evidential meaning (2010: 138-139).
The indirect evidential perfect does not combine with first person subject according to Dobrushina & Tatevosov (1996: 94).
Ingush also seems to have a special auxiliary (xanna-CM), similar to Chechen xilla (Nichols 2011: 257-259).
On a rare occasion one of the Perfects has an indirect evidential flavor (Kibrik et al. 1972: 178).

Perfect only has some evidential meaning ""in context"" according to Authier (2012: 190). No other forms described. This concerns Judeo-Tat, in the Shirvan dialect of Azerbaijan, a perfect auxiliary is used with evidential function (Murad Suleymanov, p.c.).
